t: 1 Corinthians 12
Now*p concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I would not have you ignorant.
Ye*p know that ye were Gentiles, carried away unto these dumb idols, even as ye were led.
Wherefore*p I give you to understand, that no man speaking by the Spirit of God calleth Jesus accursed: and that no man can say that Jesus is the Lord, but by the Holy Ghost.
Now*p there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit.
And*p there are differences of administrations, but the same Lord.
And*p there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God which worketh all in all.
But*p the manifestation of the Spirit is given to every man to profit withal.
For*p to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge by the same Spirit;
To*p another faith by the same Spirit; to another the gifts of healing by the same Spirit;
To*p another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another discerning of spirits; to another divers kinds of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues:
But*p all these worketh that one and the selfsame Spirit, dividing to every man severally as he will.
For*p as the body is one, and hath many members, and all the members of that one body, being many, are one body: so also is Christ.
For*p by one Spirit are we all baptized into one body, whether we be Jews or Gentiles, whether we be bond or free; and have been all made to drink into one Spirit.
For*p the body is not one member, but many.
If*p the foot shall say, Because I am not the hand, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body?
And*p if the ear shall say, Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body?
If*p the whole body were an eye, where were the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where were the smelling?
But*p now hath God set the members every one of them in the body, as it hath pleased him.
And*p if they were all one member, where were the body?
But*p now are they many members, yet but one body.
And*p the eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee: nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.
Nay,*p much more those members of the body, which seem to be more feeble, are necessary:
And*p those members of the body, which we think to be less honourable, upon these we bestow more abundant honour; and our uncomely parts have more abundant comeliness.
For*p our comely parts have no need: but God hath tempered the body together, having given more abundant honour to that part which lacked:
That*p there should be no schism in the body; but that the members should have the same care one for another.
And*p whether one member suffer, all the members suffer with it; or one member be honoured, all the members rejoice with it.
Now*p ye are the body of Christ, and members in particular.
And*p God hath set some in the church, first apostles, secondarily prophets, thirdly teachers, after that miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, governments, diversities of tongues.
Are*p all apostles? are all prophets? are all teachers? are all workers of miracles?
Have*p all the gifts of healing? do all speak with tongues? do all interpret?
But*p covet earnestly the best gifts: and yet shew I unto you a more excellent way.
